Blog.post: I walked on, sad, hurt, and disappointed at the time I had wasted and the girl behind me. I looked at my watch to see how much time I had left. The hands on my watch spun quickly; there was no concept of time here. The road ahead of me seemed to drop at my feet. I stared down at the bottom and watched the path fade into the grass. Near the end, the cobblestones had been pushed out as the grass pushed its way through the stones. I didnât know how to get down the hill; it was scary looking down at my potential death or maiming. So I sat down, closed my eyes, and started scooting down the cliff. I didnât open my eyes once, and I felt my way down until soft spring grass was completely under me. I opened my eyes and stood up. A huge field of grass stretched out ahead of me. I glanced behind and there was no path behind me at all. I smiled and ran ahead, into the center of the field. Smiling I starred up at the treeless horizon and spun. The stars above me quivered. I was happy to be away from danger. I sat down to catch my breath, and the world slowly stopped spinning, but the stars didnât. Fireflies were the first thought in my head. I reached up to grab one. âLemme go!â a shrill voice said, and I immediately opened my hand palm up. âSorry,â I said. âAgain with the touching things,â I added silently. I looked closer. âYouâre not a firefly,â I marveled. The thing in my hand appeared to be nothing but a ball of light. âWonderful deduction Dr. Obvious, anything else youâd like to tell me that I already know?â It shook sarcastically. âI just didnât know what you were, sorry.â âI am a singer,â it said melodically. âMy brothers, and sisters, and I sing people to sleep in the night sky. âReally? How wonderful, sort of like the Sandman.â âOh no!â It shook violently, âWe are much superior to the Sandman, he doesnât even do anything. We bring your dreams at night. We are the ones that lull you into the slumber that you need. We are singers.â I breathed out slowly and crossed my eyes trying to get a better look at what was in my hand. I could see nothing, but twice as many lights around me. âCould you sing for me?â I asked. The ball began to shake, and more surrounded my hand. They outlined my arms and shoulders, and I had the strange sensation of tingling in my body. I felt like I was floating, and the air was filled with a melody that I had heard before. My eyes grew heavy, and I knew I was supposed to be doing something other than sitting in this grass. I just couldnât remember what. I leaned back and watched my hands glow with the light of the singers around me. I would have twirled in their song, wrapping it around me like a blanket, if I had had the energy. Instead, all I could do was smile softly, and try to hum. I kept trying to remember what it was I was supposed to be doing. Nothing at all would come to mind. So I closed my eyes to think, and the last thing I remembered was floating on a cloud of lights, then everything went dark.

The two cats that had been following me around earlier slunk up next to me, and wrapped their bodies around my legs. Both wound up around my body until, and from behind began nudging me with their heads. I let them nudge me to my knees, and then I slowly pushed myself off the ground. Both slithered around my feet, and walked ahead of me a few steps, and paused, looking back at me at the same time, as if they were one person, to see if I was following them. âIâm coming,â I sighed, still unsure of why I knew I could talk to anything and everything here. I followed the twin cats for a long while, watching, as the trees seemed to glimmer while the night grew darker. The stars seemed dull compared to their leaves, and they sung quiet songs as I tiptoed down the path. Suddenly the cats stopped. They turned to each other, and raised their front paws as if to fight, but instead, their bodies entwined around each other to form a beautiful willowy figure dressed in a gossamer dress, that shone as bright as the trees. She was gifted with long shimmery light brown hair, and fair skin. I wanted to touch her. Then she spoke to me in the harshest of tones. âYour hair is pretty,â she said matter-of-factly as she turned pirouettes down the path and around me. âThank youâ I said confused, I didnât remember that she had once been a single spirit in the body of two cats. As she turned, her hair spiraled up into red streaked ringlets, like mine. Then she turned again, and her skin was no longer pale, it was a dark olive, like mine. She stopped twirling around me for a moment and walked up close to me. âYou look like you need help; do you want me to help you?â She shook her head and her hair fell out of the ringlets, and her skin was again fair as a china doll. I stared into her brown eyes, and they seemed truthful, but I wasnât sure, because I could see a wall behind them. I had no one to trust, however, and so I accepted her help. âWhere to?â She asked dancing down the path. âThe castleâ¦â I started. âDown yonder. The castle, down yonderâ¦â she trailed off into singing that phrase into the air as she danced around me. âAre you going to help me?â I asked a little annoyed. âOf course, Iâm helping you know. See you just need to follow me,â she continued in circles around me for what seemed like months until she finally began prancing down the path. I followed her cautiously, waiting for her to spin off the road. She stopped. âCan you dance?â she asked me raising one eyebrow. âYea,â I said unsure of what was to come next. âNot better than me,â she said pretentiously. âWhy does it matter?â I asked her. âDo you want me to help you?â She said angrily. Her clothes changed to match the pattern of my jeans and tight black t-shirt. Then they quickly shifted back to her own. She grew as tall as me, and then immediately shrunk to her own height again. Her hair kept altering from mine to hers. I looked at her strangely. Who was this girl? âYes I do, but I donât see what that has to do with you helping me,â I said backing away from her. âIf you werenât going to help me in the first place, why didnât you just say so?â She stepped up into my face. âIâm sorry I promise Iâll help you this time, but I canât help you if you are better than me. If you were better than me then you wouldnât need help,â she said into my face. I stared back at her. What was she saying to me? âWell do you need help or not?â She asked again. âYes I need your help,â I said as she spun off again, this time towards a tree, and then she sat down beside it, and began picking at a flower. âCome here,â she beckoned, and I sat next to her. She pinned a the ragged flower in my hair and smiled at the effect. âItâs not as pretty as mine,â she said pointing to the large red rose that appeared in her hair. Then it faded into pink, and then yellow, and then white. âWhich color do you like best?â âRed, I guess, look can you help me?â I said exasperated with this girl. âSure,â she said absentmindedly. I stood up, wrongly assuming she would do the same. âOkay,â I looked down at her. âMhmm,â she blinked up at me innocently. âDo you think Iâm pretty, because sometimes I think I am, and then sometimes I think not so much? What do you think?â I stared at her incredulously. âYouâve promised me your help several times. Will you help me or are you just wasting my time?â âYes youâre wasting my time, you can go. That way,â she pointed the direction we had come, and waved her other hand making a mirror appear in her hand. She examined her reflection. âI need someone else like me, hmm,â she appeared to think for a moment, and then shook her arm off. A new one grew in itâs place, and another being grew from her arm. A boy this time, with dark hair and olive skin. He sat next to her and wrapped his arms around her. âYou are beautiful,â he said to her, âAm I?â âOf course,â she giggled and batted her eyelashes at him. I stared at her sadly. So much for a promise. I shrugged and started heading the way I had been in the first place. I would have to do this on my own.

The path I was on was old cobble stone, potholes everywhere. I could easily twist my ankle, so I walked slowly, with my eyes focused on the ground ahead of me. The stones were large, curved and smooth. Most were dark brown, gray, or tan, but some were a weird shade of teal. I wondered if they werenât really stones, but eggs. I tried not to step on them in case they were, and they cracked under my weight. I stopped for a moment to see if I was still heading towards the castle. I didnât want to loose sight of it. I had no idea if that was even where I wanted to go. While I was staring into the beautiful, lavender horizon, something poked at my leg. I looked down again, afraid of what I might see. To my surprised, a tiny baby bird, with purple fuzz, had poked its head out of what I had correctly assumed were eggs. I immediately leaned down to pat its head. It pecked furiously at my hand, crying out in a voice far too loud for a baby bird to have. âShit!â I snatched my hand back, and stood up, âIâve got to remember not to touch things,â I reminded myself, and watched as more creatures emerged. Some were different color birds, and others looked like tiny moles and rabbits. All were shades of green, blue, pink, and purple that belonged under a black light. I stepped over their heads and continued walking. There were more birds than any other creature, and they pecked at my legs. I hopped from one leg to the other to reduced the pain. The animals with arms reached out and grabbed at my feet. Trying to topple me over I tried desperately to get away. Something grabbed a hold my shoe, and yanked hard. I fell and landed hard on top of several creatures, whom promptly hurried back into the ground. I pulled myself up in time to watch my shoe, and all the animals disappear under their eggs again. I took off my other shoe and threw into the woods around me. âArgh!â I screamed. Nothing, it seemed would ever go right for me here.

I looked back up at the sky. The sun had fallen down completely. The air was colder than ever. A glow was coming from the trees, and as I looked closer. I noticed the glow wasnât coming from stars like I had thought. They were coming from people. These people were perched in the trees like large birds. Some high, some low. All of them looked out of the world I was presently in. None spoke, but their glassy eyes seemed to scream. I turned away to keep from crying. A small girl with dark hair leaned back against the tree. She was a pale blue. The tree behind her was sickly, dying. Her tears shone out, frozen on her face, glowing like diamonds. âAre you okay?â I asked âNo,â she said not looking up at me. Her hair was short, and scraggly. She scratched at her head with her arm. There was a long needle stuck deep inside a vein. A small circle of her skin was the color of the tree. The blue tint of the rest of her seemed to have ruptured from the vein the needle was in. I sucked in air hard. A branch fell from the tree. âPlease, let me take that from you,â I begged her. âTake what?â She asked puzzled. âThe needle!â I said panicked. âBut I need it to live in the tree, you canât have it. I want to be up there, youâre not allowed.â âI donât want to be in your tree! Itâs dying!â I almost yelled at her. âPlease let me help youâ¦â I reached for her arm. âNo!â she snatched her arm away from me and held it close. Then she pushed the needle in deeper. âItâs not working!â She called up to the tree. It swayed in response. Decaying as it spoke. The trees around it grew larger to take away itâs space. âYouâre killing yourself,â I said softly. The girl looked up at me. Her eyes were black. âRâ scratched itself into the bark slowly as she stared at me. âYouâre lying. I canât die now. Iâm too young,â she said in a small voice. âNo, no. I can help you. Just let me take the needle out of your arm,â âIâ scratched itself next. âIf I was dying wouldnât I know?â The white around her eyes got darker. âPleaseâ¦â I said desperately, âPlease let me help you.â Her eyes were now filled in with black. âPâ was the last of the letters to be etched in the tree. âI know a secret,â she said. The tears on her face reflected me many times. âI can help you, just give me your arm. I can save you,â This time she held out her arm willingly. The needle had been shoved all the way through her skin. Nothing remained above. âBut Iâm already dead,â she said finally, staring at me, her black eyes probing my soul. The blue in her skin darkened slightly. Wings sprouted from her back. Her body lifted heavily into the air as her wings flapped. I stepped back not knowing what to think as the tree she had been at sunk into the ground leaving nothing but a pile of ashes and a small rock with her name on it. She lowered herself slowly stepped down at the ground and a tear slowly rolled down my face, she kissed it away. âDream as if youâll live forever. Live as if youâll die today,â she whispered in my ear. Then she faded away. I looked back up at these trees. All of the people in them were sad, trying to fly. I wanted to help them, they were all too far gone. I knew, that somehow, I was going to be one of them if I didnât move. So, I started walking. A boy reached down and grabbed my hair. Another girl grabbed at my shirt. I started running. Arms dropped out of the trees grabbing at me. âBut you need a tree.â âHow can you live on the ground.â âCome up here, up high, with us,â They all called at me. I ran faster. I didnât want a tree. I needed out of the forest. A path unwound itself a little farther on. I ran until I reached it. Then I slowed to a steady walk. The trees here were normal, no people were hanging out of them. I sighed and looked down the path. A long way off, I could see a castle, well the top of it really. I didnât know if that was what I was aiming for, but at least it was something. So I walked towards the castle, trying to never let it leave my sight. Author's Note: This post dedicated to the memory of Tracy Crosset (September 29, 1986 - April 11, 2004) she died from a heroin overdose.

I turned and stumbled out the door, immediately walking. I got about five steps, before I noticed that wherever I stepped, springy, soft, green grass grew swiftly under my feet. I picked up one foot, and placed it carefully in front of me. Immediately I was standing on grass again. I turned around quickly and stared at the place my house had been standing. Now there was nothing but trees. They were tall, and thick, visibly growing taller by the second. I stood in awe wondering if I was really watching vines creep slowly up those trees. I felt small, and I wanted to go back to my once comforting room. I started running, and crashed through the brush. I ran until I couldnât breathe, and then flopped down on the ground. I tried to catch my breath. Leaning back on the tree, I looked up. It was hopelessly tall, and an odd color. Not just brown, it was light tan, and thick. I reached my hand up and pushed myself up. The grass had grown to my waist. I swam through it, feeling the grass quiver around me. I was enjoying myself. I spun in circles and looked up. The sky was a lavender color, and the sun was a deep red. It was going down. Goodbye , it seemed to whisper. âGoodbye sun! Hello moon!â I called into the air. âHello stars, hello night!â Then I fell. âOuch!â I screeched, as I landed on a rock. That brought me back to reality. I was in a forest, at night, nowhere near my house, with no idea what was happening to me. The air grew cold around me, and the wind whipped around the grass, creating a cool blanket for me. I stood up. I couldnât just lie there; I had to find home, or a way out of this. I began to shiverâ¦Where the hell was I?

The first thing I heard when I got downstairs was the high pitched squealing of a pig. I turned quickly hoping to dear God that there werenât pigs flying in my house, I just wasnât ready for that. Unfortunately what I saw was much worse. The two girls who had tormented me most in elementary and middle school were sitting on my couch. Hilary, the shorter rounder girl, somewhat resembled a pig with bleach blonde hair. She had tanned herself to the brink of bacon, and it was her I heard squealing. She was wearing a mini skirt, and a shirt much to tight for her. It was hard to believe her when she claimed she was just âbig boned.â That girl was down right porky, and there was no denying it. Cassandra had been the one to make Hilary laugh. She was tall, gangly, and looked much like a tall grasshopper with freckles and light red hair. She had tried to bleach it out, but to no avail, that girlâs stringy red locks shone right through all the dyes. She sat with her arms crooked at her sides, making it look as if she was ready to hop off at any moment. Which was exactly what she did when she noticed me. âWhat are you doing here?â She demanded. I stared at her like she was nuts. âAnswer me!â âI live here. What are you doing here?â I challenged. âI donât know if Jack told you, but the party must stay on his side of the fence, you need to get out of my house. Now.â âStupid, we know you live here,â Hilary said callously. âWe live here too. Cass meant what are you doing out of your room. Youâre not supposed to be out here if motherâs not home,â I froze. Had by some horrible twist of fate had my dream landed me as sisters with these to witches. I wanted to kill them both. I imagined running a knife clear through the fleshy skin above Hilaryâs knee, and then right through Cassâs stomach. âYou bitch!â Cass screamed at me, âHow dare you! Motherâll have your head!â My mouth dropped open. âThatâs right, I know what youâre thinking, donât think we donât. So go back up stairs and lock your door. If you even try to hurt us, Mother will kill you.â âIâm not going back to my room, and the both of you are getting out of my house,â For just a moment Hilary scrunched up her face, and a snout popped right out of where her nose had been; then it was gone. Her hand flew to her face to see if what I saw was true. âLiar. Go upstairs.â She stood up and flounced right up next to Cassandra, who was hunched over, her skin was flickering green. Both were glaring at me. âGet out!â I shouted, the house shook, and Hilary fell on the floor. She squealed and shook her hands and feet flailing in the air while she tried to get up. For a moment her feet looked like a pigs. I laughed. âShut up!â Cassandra shot at me. Her skin was now a permanent green. âGet up, Pig, and get out.â Hilary sat up and glared at me. Then she noticed her feet. âAh, ah, ahâ¦Cassandra, get them off me! Look what sheâs done! Help me,â and then she saw her sister. âOh my god! Youâre turning into a bug!â Hilary scooted across the floor as quickly as she could to get away from her. Cassandra rushed to the nearest mirror. âWhat did you do to us?â She bellowed. âI didnât do anything!â Wings began slowly sprouting out of her back. Hilaryâs snout was now stuck. She was squealing more than ever, she kicked her poor little piggy feet in an effort to make them disappear. I couldnât decide whether she was more afraid of herself or Cassandra. Cassandra was tearing at her wings with her hands which were slowly becoming permanently bent into the forearms of a grasshopper. Suddenly I couldnât help it, and I began to laugh. âIf you donât turn us backâ¦â Cassandra trailed off, all she could do know was make chirping noises with the backs of her legs, and she was doing so furiously trying to convey her message. I was laughing even harder. âHelp me, please. Somebody help.â Hilary was crying, her body was still intact, but her face had completely changed. It still looked like her, but a little less burnt, and without all the hair. âIâm sorry,â she sobbed. I stopped laughing and stared at the two. Both were helpless. Cassandraâs head and neck stuck onto the body of a grasshopper. I stared at them for a long time. Cassandra furiously rubbing her back two legs together, and Hilary holding her piggy face in her piggy hands squealing and crying. It felt good to see the two of them hurt like they had hurt me in the past, but I was still upset for them. Finally I turned away, I didnât want to feel pity for them. They were evil, and I never wanted to feel any emotion towards them. So I left hoping that I wouldnât have to deal with them again. It was hard enough just trying to convince myself this was a dream without the two of them causing problems.

âOh God, what is going on?â I said softly hoping that nothing answered me. I knew I had to go somewhere, and do something, but I didnât know what it was I was supposed to be doing. The keys to my car were glowing faintly on my desk, so I figured I might as well try and drive to wherever it was I was supposed to go. I reached out for my keys, and just as I got close enough to grab them, they slid onto the floor. I ignored the fact that nothing was there to make them fall, and bent down to pick them up. This time, they rolled across the room. âOkay, what the hell is this?â I said to them. They didnât respond to me, although I did hear the faint sound of laughter coming from their direction. My parents hadnât left their cars at home, so I needed to get these keys, and I wasnât planning on chasing them down the hallway. âCome here,â I demanded hoping against all hope that they would hop into my hands. No such luck, they scooted out my door. I sighed, and leaned against the wall. Okay , I thought, I just need to breathe and walk quietly out my door and grab the keys. So I counted to ten, and walked sideways out of my room, my back pressed against the wall. Silently, I lowered myself to the floor. With one swift move, I snatched up my keys. âYes!â I shouted pumping my fists in the air, and then something bit me. Then again, and once more as hard as something could possibly bite me. âFuck!â I screamed, and dropped the keys. I held my hand in the other and stared down at it. There were three sharp incisions where it looked as if the keys had dug themselves deep into my skin. âWhat the hell am I supposed to do now?â I screamed at the ceiling. My keys snickered, and rolled off the edge of my balcony. I wasnât planning on picking them up again, so I figured I might as well walk. I headed down the stairs, and straight for the door.

By the time I had gotten back inside, I had started to notice things were different. Everything in my house had somehow gotten bigger, and if it was even possible, louder. There was a faint humming noise coming from my room too, and as I got closer, it intensified. Slowly, with each step, I began to distinguish different songs in the jumbled up mess that was the noise. But the closer I got, the faster they got, until all I could hear was screeching. As soon as I was in my room, I noticed that the screeching was coming from the flower-shaped rugs on my floor. âIâm insane, this is insaneâ¦Iâm crazy. No Iâm dreamingâ¦â I tried to calm myself down, it wasnât working, and the noises werenât helping. I covered my ears to drown out the noise, and tried to walk backwards out of my room. Any movements I made just made the noise worse, I was weighted to the floor, and if I took one more step, I was sure I was going to explode. âSTOP IT!â I screamed shutting my eyes as tightly as they would close. The notes danced across my eyelids turning cartwheels and flip-flops. I stared entranced at their gracefulness, and then I noticed that the noise had stopped. My eyes flew open. There, sitting on my window seat, was what appeared to be a bum. He looked as if he wasnât any taller than my hip, and his skin was a dark chocolate. He had long dreadlocks, and a perfectly shaped goatee. His clothes were green, brown, and baggy; they looked like they hadnât been washed in ages, and the fact that they were the color of dirt didnât help much either. His eyes were closed and there was a quiet bubbling noise in the room as he inhaled smoke from his glossy, green bong. âStop what?â He asked me calmly when he finished, looking up at me from behind a pair of thick-rimmed, square shaped glasses. âWho the fuck are you?â I asked staring at him my eyes as wide as they would go. âNo my friend, the question is who do you think I am,â he stood up and walked towards me. âYou see, a wise man once said, âThe way we imagine ourselves to appear to another person is an essential element in our conception of ourselves. In other words, I am not what I think I am, and I am not what you think I am. I am what I think you think I am.ââ I looked down at him stunned, was this thing really talking to me? I had no idea what the hell was going on. âYou are clearly a figment of my imagination, Iâm dreaming. I have to beâ¦Iâll wake up, and this will all be over. Because youâre not real, and my rugs arenât singing. This is obviously a really weird dream,â I rationalized. I sat down and leaned my head against my dresser, covering my head with my hands. âIf thatâs what you think,â he walked over to my big comfy chair and sat down in it. The chair engulfed his tiny-ness. He inhaled again, and blew the smoke out the nose. It curled up underneath and drew shadows in the air. A bird appeared and flew through my window. âI think you are just scared. Relax, breathe, feel the air, and realize what you came here to do. What is your purpose?â I stared at the ground for a long time as I breathed in deeply, why was I listening to this, this leprechaun? However, the breathing was relaxing me, maybe it was the smoke, and maybe it wasnât, but I was calming down. âMy purpose,â I said with a sigh, âis to finish my English paper,â I stared at my computer screen. There were flying toasters on it, which I knew wasnât my screen saver. One of the pieces of toast buttered itself and jumped in the toaster. Another hopped into a pot of jam. I shook my head and looked at the leprechaun, whom I had decided to call Bob. âIâm obviously not going to be able to do that now, because my computer has gone insane too.â âDo you think youâre insane?â âYes.â âWell I donât think youâre insane, this is all very real.â âReal compared to what? This is nothing but a dream! And youâre nothing but a leprechaun in my head.â âWell Iâm not in your head. I seem to be sitting on a rather comfortable chair,â he blew a ring of smoke at me. It crowned itself on my head. I shook my head in an effort to remove it, and stared at him. âWell if youâre real, why are you here, in my room, talking to me?â âTo help you realize your path. You have something that needs completing, and if itâs not done soon, youâll end up like me my friend.â âLike you?â I snorted, and the crown jumped, âA poor, destitute, cracked out, leprechaun giving people advice they didnât ask for.â âDonât play games. This is no laughing matter. Stand up!â Something in his voice made me jump to my feet. I stood rigid waiting for him to tell me what to do. âThink hard, my friend, what is it you need the most?â âAn explanation.â âOf what?â âOf you.â âI am of no concern,â he blew smoke out the side of his mouth, it curled up to the ceiling as if he was a chimney. âHow can I trust you then?â âMy story is quite simple. I had a path too, except I wandered off. Tricked by a dumb white rabbit. I ended up like this. Now unless you want to end up giving people advice they donât ask for the rest of your life, I suggest you listen,â he stared at me, inhaling more. I stared back waiting for him to speak again. Years flew by in time. Hours twirled around minutes, making them seem longer. My internal clock stopped. âListen to what?â I asked. He held his finger to his lips. âShhh, to your heart,â he closed his eyes. I followed suit. âLove,â came a deep, resounding voice from my chest.
